ygData.msgSnippet: ... I ll make a note and we ll have to see what santa has in his sack this year :) ... Hmm, but does this give any advantage over the extra neuron functions?

Ian Badcoe wrote:

>At 20:27 21/09/2004 +0100, you wrote:
>  
>
>> <>
>> one possible direction I will be taking SharpNEAT is to introduce a few
>> more possible activation functions - multiplication being one. So I
>> really think this blurs the lines between GP and TWEANs somewhat.
>
>
>I think that's a good way to go, just blurring the line a very little 
>because NEAT works _much_ better than the average GP...
>
>(Just to inspire you and not as any sort of demand :) wish list of 
>activation functions:
>
>Sum
>Sigmoid
>Multiply
>Difference (higher output the more variety in the inputs)
>Similarity (1/difference)
>Mode (copies the middle input)
>Max
>Min
>Sum of squares
>Step
>
>(and all of these might come in 0 to 1 and -1 to +1 varieties, or is that a 
>red-herring?)
>  
>
I'll make a note and we'll have to see what santa has in his sack this 
year :)

>Also, how about types of connection, e.g:
>
>Simple Weight
>Weight and Clamp to Max
>Weight and Clamp to Min
>Abs
>Weight and square
>  
>
Hmm, but does this give any advantage over the extra neuron functions? 
If you want the output from a neuron to have different functions applied 
to it then just define some new neurons and apply the function there. 
Thus I think this would expand the search space without actually 
improving the possibility of finding good solutions.

>Not that I'm trying to make it insanely complex :)
>  
>
I'm a great believer in keeping things simple, it's all food for thought 
though - not that I'm short on that at the moment, there are far more 
ideas floating around this list than I could possibly find time to 
investigate :(

Colin.
